summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team in support of a motion to suppress evidence and dismiss counts. The motion argues that the government's grand jury subpoena to a third party (redacted) for Maxwell's confidential deposition transcripts from a civil case violated the Fourth Amendment (overbroad, warrantless search/seizure), the Martindell doctrine (bypassing protective order procedures), and the Fifth Amendment (self-incrimination). The defense seeks suppression of all evidence obtained from the subpoena and dismissal of Counts Five and Six.

events.title: Maxwell's April 2016 Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell gave deposition testimony in a prior civil defamation case. This testimony was protected by a confidentiality order.

events.title: Maxwell's July 2016 Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell gave further deposition testimony in the prior civil defamation case. This testimony was also protected by a confidentiality order.

events.title: Filing of Suppression Motion
events.description: Maxwell's defense team files this memorandum in support of a motion to suppress evidence obtained from a grand jury subpoena and to dismiss Counts Five and Six.

keyFacts: The government obtained Ghislaine Maxwell's confidential deposition transcripts from a prior civil case via a grand jury subpoena issued to a third party (redacted in the text).

Maxwell's defense argues the subpoena was unconstitutionally overbroad, constituting a warrantless search and seizure in violation of the Fourth Amendment, as it sought an entire file without probable cause or a warrant.

The defense contends the government violated the Martindell doctrine by bypassing the proper procedure to modify a protective order, failing to give Maxwell notice and an opportunity to be heard before obtaining the confidential materials.

The motion argues that obtaining the deposition transcripts violated Maxwell's Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination, as she testified in the civil case relying on the confidentiality of the protective order.
The defense seeks suppression of all evidence obtained from the subpoena, specifically the April and July 2016 depositions, and dismissal of Counts Five and Six of the indictment.
